benchmark_details.name: HLB (Humanlikeness Benchmark)
benchmark_details.overview: This benchmark evaluates the humanlikeness of language models through 10 psycholinguistic experiments analyzing core linguistic aspects including sound, word, syntax, semantics, and discourse. It employs a comprehensive comparison between outputs from language models and human responses to assess the extent to which these models replicate human language patterns.

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: To provide a systematic and comprehensive evaluation of how closely large language models align with human linguistic behavior.
purpose_and_intended_users.limitations: While the benchmark covers a wide range of linguistic tasks, it may not encompass the full complexity of human language use.

data.source: Responses collected from over 2,000 human participants and outputs from 20 large language models.
data.annotation: Responses were analyzed using a coding algorithm that identifies language use patterns.

metrics: Humanlikeness score (HS) based on Jensen-Shannon divergence
methodology.calculation: Humanlikeness scores are calculated by comparing response distributions between human participants and language models.
methodology.interpretation: Scores reflect the degree of alignment between model outputs and human language patterns.
methodology.baseline_results: Scores from human participants serve as the baseline for evaluation.
methodology.validation: Responses validated through statistical methods to ensure accuracy of coding.

targeted_risks.demographic_analysis: Analysis of demographic factors, focusing on native English speakers from the UK and US.
targeted_risks.harm: Identifying areas where models diverge from human-like language patterns, particularly in complex linguistic tasks.

ethical_and_legal_considerations.consent_procedures: Participants provided consent prior to participating in the experiments.
